questions.text: Which of the following is secreted from acidophilic cells of pituitary?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone is secreted from acidophilic cells of anterior pituitary.

Acidophilic cells secrete growth hormone and prolactin.

Basophilic cells secrete TSH, ACTH, FSH and LH. 

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is suffering from hypertension, buffalo hump and hyperpigmentation of the skin, including oral mucosa. He is diagnosed with Cushing syndrome due to pituitary cause. Which of the following is responsible for the hyperpigmentation seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
ACTH is more responsible than MSH for the hyperpigmentation seen in a patient with Cushing syndrome due to pituitary cause (ACTH hypersecretion).

ACTH is a derivative of POMC (Pro-opiomelanocortin). POMC is the precursor of ACTH, melanocyte­ stimulating hormone (MSH), β ­lipotropin and β ­endorphin.  Since the melanocyte-stimulating hormone is the byproduct of ACTH synthesis from POMC, any disease process which leads to ACTH overproduction will also lead to an increased level of MSH. ACTH has mild MSH activity, hence elevated levels of ACTH acts on melanotropin-1 receptors causing generalized hyperpigmentation.

A similar manifestation will also be seen in Addison's disease where the ACTH level is high.

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted mainly on prolactin and growth hormone.

The major hypothalamic releasing hormones are:

  • Thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH)
  • Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH)
  • Growth hormone releasing hormone (GHRH)
  • Gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH)

The major hypothalamic inhibitory hormones are: 

  • Prolactin inhibitory hormone or dopamine
  • Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (GHIH), also called Somatostatin.

questions.text: A patient with a known brain tumour learns that his pituitary stalk has been affected. Secretion of which of the following hormones is increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk?
questions.solution:
The secretion of prolactin is increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk. 

Prolactin is unique among the pituitary hormones because the predominant central control mechanism is inhibitory, i.e., dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. Hence, sectioning of the pituitary stalk (Ex: In head trauma or compressive skull lesions) prevents this inhibition and leads to increased secretion of prolactin. 

Note:

If the pituitary stalk is cut above the pituitary gland but the entire hypothalamus is left intact, the posterior pituitary hormones (ADH & Oxytocin) show a transient decrease because they are initially synthesized in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus and are then transported down to the nerve endings to the posterior pituitary gland, requiring several days to reach the gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of elevated prolactin level?
questions.solution:
L- Dopa is not a cause of increased prolactin level, it decreases prolactin secretion by increasing the formation of dopamine (prolactin inhibitory hormone).

questions.text: Which of the following is the effect of continuous GnRH administration?
questions.solution:
Continuous GnRH administration suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

Pulsatile GnRH stimulates the pulsatile release of LH and FSH.

Note: Long-acting GnRH agonists are used to suppress gonadotropin levels in children with precocious puberty and in men with prostate cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following actions of GH is mediated by IGF–1?
questions.solution:
Antilipolysis is mediated by IGF-1.

The actions of growth hormone-mediated via IGF-1 (somatomedin-C) are the indirect effects of growth hormone and include:

  • Antilipolytic activity
  • Insulin-like activity
  • Protein synthesis
  • Epiphyseal growth

The direct effects of GH include:

  • Sodium retention
  • Decreased insulin sensitivity
  • Lipolysis
  • Protein synthesis
  • Epiphyseal growth 

Related Pearl: Direct and Indirect (mediated via IGF-1) effects of Growth Hormone

Indirect effects of growth hormone are mediated via IGF-I. 

Direct effects of GH are shown below.

questions.text: GH has its effect on bone growth through______
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) has both direct and indirect effects on bone growth.

GH stimulates prechondrocytes to differentiate into chondrocytes. GH strongly stimulates osteoblasts and chondrocytes causing increased deposition of proteins → bone growth. GH also increases insulin-like growth factor (IGF) levels, which stimulate bone growth. 

Note: The pygmies of Africa have a congenital inability to synthesize significant amounts of somatomedin C (IGF-I). Therefore, even though their plasma concentration of growth hormone is either normal or high, they have diminished amounts of IGF-I in the plasma, which accounts for the short stature. Some other dwarfs (e.g., the Levi-Lorain dwarf) also have this problem.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones demonstrates the fluctuations depicted below?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, (Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM sleep)

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.text: Growth hormone level is decreased in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone(GH) level is decreased during deep sleep. Specifically, it is reduced during REM sleep as the levels of GHRH reduces and levels of cortisol are higher compared to slow wave sleep.

Hypoglycemia, fasting, and exercise cause an increase in GH secretion. GH levels are increased during non-REM sleep.   

GH levels also decline with age and obesity.

questions.text: A 35 yr old man presents with hypertension, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, large hands and feet, mandibular enlargement and a large fleshy nose. His age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acromegaly and is due to excess growth hormone (GH).

Acromegaly occurs when excessive GH is secreted after puberty (after fusion of long bone epiphysis). Features include

  • Prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones
  • Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues)
  • Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver, spleen, kidney, and prostate

Serious complications include cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. Age-matched IGF-I levels are elevated.

questions.text: What does the neurohypophysis release?
questions.solution:
The posterior pituitary or neurohypophysis releases oxytocin and anti-diuretic hormone (ADH or vasopressin) 

Note: ADH and oxytocin are synthesised by the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus. Thereafter, they are stored and released from the posterior pituitary.

Vasopressin mediates its effect via 3 kinds of receptors- V1a, V1b and V2. There is no V4.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of vasopressin (ADH) leads eventually to downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors. This prevents excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels and hence maintains euvolemia. This is known as vasopressin escape. This helps prevent excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH.

questions.text: Sodium-iodide symport is absent in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Sodium-iodide symport is absent in the pituitary.

Na+/I– symporter is present in

  • Basolateral membranes of thyrocytes facing the capillar­ies.
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis and a positive antibody titer against thyroid peroxidase enzyme. Which of the following is not a function of the affected enzyme?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.  

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter 
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by follicular cells.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine)  in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone

questions.text: A patient with hyperthyroidism is planned for thyroidectomy. In order to achieve a euthyroid status preoperatively, he is started on Lugol's iodine solution. Which of the following best describes its mechanism of action?

choices.text: Inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones

questions.solution:
Introduction of exogenous iodine in the form of lugol's iodine solution leads to transient inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. This is known as the wolff-chaikoff effect.

In individuals with a normal thyroid, the gland escapes from this inhibitory effect and iodide organification resumes; but the suppressive action of high iodide may persist in patients with hyperthyroidism due to underlying autoimmune thyroid disease.

Note: Jod-Basedow effect is iodine-induced hyperthyroidism, usually occurring after the use of an I-based contrast agent. It is often seen in the presence of pre-existing thyroid conditions like multinodular goitre.

questions.text: How long is thyroxine stored in thyroid follicles?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine is stored in the thyroid follicles for 2-3 months, bound to thyroglobulin. 

Serves as a reserve of T3 and T4, thus delaying the occurrence of hypothyroidism, if thyroid secretion ceases.

questions.text: The major thyroxine-binding protein is _____.
questions.solution:
Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) is the major thyroxine-binding protein.

Other thyroxine-binding proteins are:

  • Albumin
  • Transthyretin (TTR)/ thyroxine-binding pre-albumin (TBPA)
  • Lipoproteins

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding thyroid hormone?

choices.text: T3 is more avidly bound to nuclear receptor than T4
T3 is more active than T4
T4 has shorter half- life than T3

questions.solution:
T4 doesn't have a shorter half-life than T3, rather  T3 has a shorter half-life and more rapid action than T4.

questions.text: Half-life of T4_____
questions.solution:
The half-life of T4 is 6 - 7 days.

T3 has the shorter half-life of 1 day.

questions.text: A 35 yr old woman presents with heat intolerance and menstrual abnormalities. On examination, a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland is present. Which of the following features will not be present in her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperthyroidism, which does not cause decreased protein breakdown. Rather it causes increased protein breakdown.

questions.text: Prolactin level is highest during :
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery. 

The maximum level of prolactin is seen during pregnancy and in the immediate postpartum period. During pregnancy, the secretion is increased reaching a peak at the time of delivery. After delivery, the plasma concentration falls to nonpregnant levels in a few weeks. Suckling produces surges of prolactin release.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

Cushing’s disease is caused by an ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma. The increased ACTH causes increased cortisol production.

Note: In normal physiologic state, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.
